metadata.title: Electrodeposition and corrosion behavior of nano-structured Ni-WC and Ni-Co-WC composite coating

sections.text:

Electrodeposition and corrosion behavior of nano-structured Ni-WC and Ni-Co-

sections.heading: WC composite coating.
sections.text:
N. Elkhoshkhany, Ahmed Hafnway, Alaa Khaled. Department of Materials Science, Institute of Graduate Studies and Researches, Alexandria
University,163 Horrya Avenue, Shatby, 21526, Alexandria, Egypt.
Abstract Composite coating of metallic-ceramics tungsten carbide (WC) in nickel matrix has been achieved by direct current (DC) electrodeposition using watt's bath solution on stainless steel substrate. The deposition parameters such as current density, bath temperature, and stirring rate were maintained at constant levels for all the coating configurations. The surface morphologies, microstructure, and chemical composition of the composite coating were studied using scanning electron microscope (SEM), Xray diffraction (XRD), and energy dispersive analyzer x-ray system (EDX), respectively. The surface morphology and microstructure analysis showed that the composite coatings form cauliflower-like grain colonies, grain size was calculated from Scherrer equation it was less than 60 nm for all composite coating. Micro hardness of composite coating was increased by increasing WC load in solution and decreasing grain size. The electrochemical corrosion behavior of composite coating was evaluated by potentiodynamic polarization measurements and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) in aerated 0.5 mol/l H2SO4 at room temperature, showing passivation behavior of all composite coating, good protection of Ni-8g/l WC on stainless steel substrate. Keywords: Metallic-ceramic; Electrodeposition; Nano-composite tungsten carbide coatings; Corrosion behavior.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
1-Introduction Composite coatings including Electrodeposition of fine particles into a metal matrix are widely used in many applications such as aerospace and automotive industry. In recent years, many types of research were carried out on Ni matrix coatings reinforced by ceramic particles, such as Ni-Al[1,2], Ni−SiC[3], Ni−WC[4], Ni−ZrC[5], Ni−TiO2[6] to improvements of hardness, wear resistance, and corrosion properties. Electrodeposition is an excellent and inexpensive tool to produce materials from thick metal deposits with a very large surface area to ultra thin metal films with a few nanometer sizes[7]. Low carbon steels are widely used in engineering applications, because of their low cost, good formability, and weld ability. However, low mechanical properties, hardness, and corrosion resistance restrict their widespread use and application, Therefore, coating technology is emerging as a viable technique to alter the properties of the material by natural or artificial deposition of another material on the bulk phase of the solid[8]. Surface modification can be applied by several methods like electro - deposition[9], high-velocity oxygen fuel (HVOF)[10] , thermal spraying[11], plasma spraying[12], hot isostatic pressing [13] and vapor deposition process [14]. Group VI transition metal carbides have received considerable attention for their unique physical and chemical properties such as high melting point, high hardness high fracture toughness, high compressive strength, resistance to non-oxidizing acids and good electrical and thermal conductivity[15]. Tungsten carbide WC or WC–Co is a technologically important material and has been widely used as cutting tools, rock drills, punches and wear-resistant coating materials [16]. The idea has been extended to replace electrodeposited chromium coatings with nano-structured nickel dispersion coatings. Tungsten carbides with cobalt binder WC–
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT
ED
Co have high hardness and strength from the carbide with some toughness from the cobalt binder[17]. Most of these researches focused on wear properties, The interest in corrosionresistant electroplated nickel coatings was traced back to the promising results of other nanocrystalline materials and the possibility to decrease the nickel grain size due to the incorporation of nano-scaled particles ,the growth of WC grains is concerned, a highly distorted lattice. It is essential to make sure that good anti-corrosion properties of coatings are preserved, especially if they are to work in aggressive media[7,18]. Both WC and Co form an oxide film in an aerated environment which leads to protective of the underlining metal[11,19,20]. In this work, Ni-WC and Ni-Co-WC composite coatings were prepared on stainless steel surfaces using electrodeposition process and studying their performance as corrosion barriers for industrial applications and improve mechanical properties.
2-Material and methods 2.1-materials
Table 1 shows the materials used and its characteristic features. With the addition of Sulphuric acid and ammonia solution were purchased from Elnasr pharmaceutical Chemical Company, Egypt. Ethanol (96%) was purchased from Chemajet Company, Egypt. All reagents were used as received without further purification. 2.2 - Preparation of composite coating. Stainless steel substrate 2cm2 x 2cm2 was the working electrode Prior to all experiments abraded with a series of emery papers of different grades (400–1200), degreased with ethanol for 5 min to remove any oxide film from the surface, and rinsed with deionized water and let it to dray at air.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
Ni-WC composites were electrodeposited from an organic free Watt’s nickel electrolyte with suspended ultrafine WC particles. The composition of the plating solution, as well as the plating parameters, is given in, Table 2. Ni-Co-WC has same plating parameters in Table 2, the composition of plating solution Ni-Co-WC presented in Table 3. WC particles maintained in the electrolytic bath in suspension by continuous magnetic stirring with a rate of 1000 rpm for at least 24 h before deposition. The WC particles added to electrolyte with different load 2,4,6,8 g/l. temperatures were maintained by water circulation at a thermostatic value of 500C, and the pH of the solution was adjusted to a constant value of 4.2 by appropriate additions of H2SO4 or NH3 solutions. The rate of magnetic stirring was employed during electrodeposition at 300 rpm at the cell bottom in order to maintain a uniform concentration of particles in the bulk solution. The platinum plate was used as an anode and stainless steel substrate was used as a cathode. The distance between the anode and the cathode was maintained at 4cm. 2.3 – Surface characterization. The surface morphologies were studies using a Scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL-JSM-5300).The compositions of composite coatings were studied by Energy dispersive analyzer x-ray system (EDX, JEOL-JSM-6360LA). The phase structure of the composite coating was analyzed by X-ray diffractometer (GNR,APD-2000pro Xray diffractometer) operated at 40 kV and 30 mA with CuKα radiation by scanning speed 0.030/sec. Hardness of the materials was assessed using a Microhardness tester (M-83715) with a load of 200g for 15 sec. the electrochemical measurements were performed in a typical three compartment glass cell consisted of the coating samples electrode after ultra sonication for 5 min as the working electrode (WE) with a 1 cm2 surface area, a platinum foil as the counter electrode (PE) and a saturated calomel
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
electrode (SCE) as the reference electrode (RE). Polarization and impedance measurements were performed using a Gamry PCI4G750 Potentiostat/Galvanostat/ZRA analyzer, with a Gamry framework system based on ESA400. Gamry applications include DC105 corrosion software, and EIS300 software for potentiodynamic polarization and EIS measurements, respectively, and Echem Analyst 5.5 software for results plotting, graphing, data fitting & calculating. For potentiodynamic polarization experiments, the potential in the range of _0.6 V to +1.5 V relative to the open circuit potential.with a scan rate of 5 mV s-1 at aerated 0.5mol/l H2SO4 at room temperature. Impedance measurements were performed at open circuit potential over a frequency range of 0.1 Hz to 0.1 MHz with a 10 mV peak-to-peak amplitude using the AC signal.The corrosion current density (icorr) for the specimens was determined by extrapolating the anodic and cathodic Tafel slopes. All EIS spectra were analyzed in Nyquist representation.

sections.heading: 3.1- Surface morphology studies.
sections.text:
3.1.1- SEM of Ni-WC and Ni-Co-WC nano composite coating. Surface morphology of Ni-WC and Ni-Co-WC composite coatings prepared under DC condition with ω=300 rpm presented by scanning electron microscope SEM. Deposit of Ni coating has regular pyramid structure as(S. Mohajeri, a. Dolati, S. Rezagholibeiki) shown in figure.1[7] . when WC particles added in the solution the particles precipitate in grain interfaces and obstacle grain growth, thus structure transforms from pyramidal to global that's shown in the figure.2, the overall appearance is representative of an "open-like" structure consisted of WC particles (gray-colored areas) arranged on the Ni crystallite
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
(dark-colored areas) that a Cauliflower surface morphology is evident [4,21]. By increase concentration of WC particles porosity decrease and have a more homogenous structure as shown in the figure.2, at (a)-Ni-2g/l WC at low concentration, WC has low dispersion, at (b)-Ni-8g/l WC as the concentration of WC increase dispersion increase homogenously and porosity decrease. In Ni-Co-WC composite coating, when cobalt added to the system it gives denser homogenous nanostructure, increases with increase concentration of WC which improves surface morphology of deposited coating , as cobalt have a larger radius than tungsten it forms more "open-like" structure[22]. Figure.3 show Ni-Co-WC coating on stainless steel substrate with different concentration of WC, at Ni-Co-8g/l WC it shows more dense cauliflower homogenous structure with low porosity[23]. Figure.4 illustrate the difference in cross-section structure between Ni-WC and NiCo-WC coating layers founded that coating thickness increase when cobalt particles added, structure grained perpendicular to the substrate plate is clearly visible in such Ni-Co-WC electrodeposited[24].
3.1.2- EDX analysis of Ni-WC and Ni-Co-WC composite coating. Chemical composition was determined by Energy dispersive analyzer system EDX. Table.4 shows the weight percentage of W and Co. It appeared that Ni-WC and NiCo-WC are homogenously dispersion on the substrate surface. It was founded that the amount of tungsten content in surface coating increase with increase its concentration in solution from 9.15 (wt%) in Ni-2g/l WC to 43.9 (wt%) in Ni-8g/l WC, and from 4.19 (wt%) in Ni-Co-2g/l WC to 25.64 (wt%) in Ni-Co-8g/l WC. from comparing (a)with(c) ,and (b)with(d) in table 4, it was founded that the amount of tungsten
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
decrease when adding cobalt in composite coating layer and amount of carbide increase.
3.1.3- XRD analysis of Ni-WC and Ni-Co-WC composite coating. The XRD pattern of Ni-8 g/l WC composite coating was shown in the figure.5, Ni and WC peaks are found well and sharp peaks, Ni matrix with face-centered cubic (fcc) crystal structure as field phase (PDF number:01-078-7536) and short WC peaks with hexagonal crystal structure as reinforcement phase as the second phase (PDF number:01-089-2727), it’s the same XRD peaks position of Ni-WC in the previous study[4]. Figure.6 show the XRD pattern of Ni-Co-WC composite coating, peaks corresponding to Co phase were not found in the spectra, indicating that the crystal lattice in WC matrix perhaps had been replaced partly by Co binder and formed solid solution[25] but the presence of Co in the composite coating confirming by energy dispersive spectroscopy EDX result. Figure.6 show different in intensity of WC peaks as concentration of tungsten carbide increase in the solution, figure.6 (a) Ni-Co- 2g/l WC at low concentration of tungsten carbide, (b) Ni-Co- 8g/l WC at high concentration of tungsten carbide, it observed that as concentration of tungsten carbide increase in solution the intensity of its diffraction peaks increase. Grain size calculated by Scherrer equation:
= . Ө (1)
where k was the figure factor of the grain (k=0.9), λ was the wavelength (λ=1.540598 Å), β was the width at half height of the diffraction peak and Ө was the Bragg angle[26]. Table.5 shows average grain size of main highest peaks for Ni at the 2-

theta peak values 44.73 and 52.01 with (111) and (200) miller indices and for WC at the 2-theta peak values 31.73, 35.88 and 48.55 with (001), (100) and (101) miller indices. All grain sizes founded less than 60 nm the grain size of Ni decrease with increase concentration of WC, when cobalt added the Ni grain size become smaller 37.20 nm it can be concluded that embedding WC and Co particles into Ni matrix can refine the grain size.

sections.heading: 3.2- Hardness of coatings.
sections.text:
As tungsten carbide is a hard metal it expected to improve mechanical properties of nickel matrix, measuring hardness by microhardness indenter load 200g for 15 sec hardness via a load of WC in solution can be drawn in a curve as shown in figure.7. It's observed that with increase WC load in Ni-WC deposit coating hardness increase comparable with stainless steel substrate and Ni coating deposit, it can be due to three factors (i) composition and grain size of Ni–WC, (ii) content and distribution of WC, and (iii) microstructure as induced by WC incorporation[22]. WC particles create a new location of nucleation on a surface of Ni matrix which leads to refinement of grains ,thus the grain boundaries expand and hinder the motion of dislocation as result hardness increase[7]. In Ni-Co-WC composite coating as result of adding cobalt to system, hardness has increased dramatically from 218 for Ni coating to 1048 for Ni-Co-8g/l WC as shown in figure.8[16], that due to Co has more large radius than WC which creates more "open –like " nano dense and homogenous structure, the amount of carbide particles increase due to decarburization of WC as shown from EDX result in section 3.1.2[27]. Hardness appears to be closely related to microstructure in the general refinement of
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
grain structure showed improvement in hardness, as we compare the cross section of Ni-WC and Ni-Co-WC coating layer we found cross section increase from 0.81 µm in Ni-WC to 3.86 µm in Ni-Co-WC as shown in figure.4. It observed that hardness of coating layer linearly depends on coating thickness[28].

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrochemical behavior.
sections.text:
3.3.1 Open circuit potential. The open circuits potential values of the stainless steel substrate, Ni coating and composite coating material of (Ni-WC) and (Ni-Co-WC) measure in aerated 0.5 mol/l H2 SO4,are compared in figure.9. The open circuit potential of Ni-8g/l WC was much nobler than substrate, Ni coating, and Ni-Co-WC, that's due to two reasons: (i) The open circuit potential difference between WC particles Co binder material causes micro galvanic corrosion between them in the acidic environment, the WC become cathodic and Co binder material become anodic resulting in corrosion of anodic binder. (ii) observed from EDX result as the concentration increase in Ni-Co-WC composite coating the content of tungsten decreasing while cobalt content increasing and amount of carbide increase too which lead to the low corrosion resistance of Ni-CoWC[11,29]. 3.3.2 Anodic potentiodynamic polarization behavior. The anodic polarization behavior of Ni-WC and Ni-Co-WC coatings were examined using aerated 0.5 mol/l H2SO4 solution in the potential range _0.6 V to +1.5 V. The anodic polarization profiles of all coatings are shown in Figure10 and Tafel polarization curve result are given in table.6. The curve (1) and (2) in Figure10
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
represents the polarization behavior of stainless steel substrate and Ni coating respectively, where as curves from (3) to (10) represents the polarization behavior of Ni-WC and Ni-Co-WC composite coating layers. All composite coatings Ni-2g/l WC, Ni-4g/l WC, Ni-6g/l WC, Ni-8g/l WC, Ni-Co-2g/l WC, Ni-Co-4g/l WC, Ni-Co-6g/l WC and Ni-Co-8g/l WC showed active-passive behavior with respect to the stainless steel substrate and Ni coating. by comparing the results in the table.6, that found Ni-8 g/l WC shows much nobler Ecorr and lowest Icorr thus potentially better corrosion resistance in the active region with further polarization at anodic direction (positive shift) as shown in figure.11[30,31,32]. The percentage inhibition efficiency (µ) for Ni-8 g/l WC was calculated from,
µ =
ₒ
ₒ 100 (2)
Where (icorr)o and corr the are the corrosion current of the metal in uninhibited and inhibited solutions, it found to be almost 79% [30]. As shown in the figure.11 the curve can be divided into the two distinct regions, at region (I) the current density of the coating layers exhibited the initial exponential increase with increasing the potential and then remained nearly unchanged with the further potential increase. These due to passivation behavior occur due to the formation of the oxide film from tungsten and cobalt on a metal surface, but cobalt oxide film in acidic media dissolve and continuous dissolution of cobalt occur (equations from 6 to 9) [33,34]. At region (II) all coating layer exhibited the rapid increase of current densities with increase the potential, similar typical trans-passive behavior. the corrosion not metallic corrosion but it's due to oxygen evolution by break down of water in electrolyte [35].

3.3.3. Electrochemical impedance. The same three electrode cell stack, as used for the potentiodynamic polarization experiments, was employed for the AC impedance investigations. Impedance measurements were made at the frequency range of 0.1 Hz to 0.1 MHz. The Nyquist plots for the samples used for corrosion tests in aerated 0.5 mol/l H2SO4 solution are shown in Figure 12. When the samples are immersed in the electrolyte the defects in the coating provide the direct diffusion path for the corrosive media. In this process, the galvanic corrosion cells are formed which dominate the corrosion process. The proposed equivalent circuit for such a system is shown in Figure 13. The parameters
in the equivalent circuit Rpore and Ccoat are related to the properties of the coating
and the electrolyte/coating interface reactions, where Rpo (pore resistance) is the resistance of ion conducting paths the developed in the coating and Cc is intact coating. Rct and Cdl are related to the charge–transfer reaction at the electrolyte/ substrate interface. The increase in Rct values and decrease in Cdl values for the Ni-8g/l WC confirm the better corrosion resistance of these systems compared to pure Ni coating, showed in table 7 [36,37].

sections.heading: 3.4 formation mechanism of the present coating layers
sections.text:
3.4.1- Mechanism of nickel electro-crystallization in the presence of WC particles. Ni and W complex ions were reduced and deposited on a substrate. In parallel, WC particles may be convectively transferred to the cathode surface and incorporated with the metal ions. It can be anticipated, therefore, that the transport rates of deposited metal ions and of particles would determine the structure of the electrodeposits. While
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
the growth rate of the metal film may be controlled by the deposition current, the particle incorporation rate is influenced by the dispersion of particles, which was affected by agitation of electrolyte and particles size and concentration[22]. WC is thermodynamically unstable and was oxidized in the presence of water or oxygen at room temperature. Showed that the as-received WC powder was oxidized on the surface, and the oxidized surface layer mainly consists of WO3. The WO3 could be hydrated and OH groups dominate the surface. These surface groups can result in a negative surface charge according to the reaction,
W-OH ↔ W-O-+H+ (4)
Surface complexes could be formed at the interface of WC particles in a Ni+2 acidic aqueous solutions, by a reaction such as,
W-OH + Ni +Cl ↔ W-O.Ni Cl + H (5) which subsequently can induced absorption of Ni–W and H cations on the particles, forming surface complexes [21]. Consequently, incorporation of such cation absorbed WC particles into the alloy deposits may be facilitated, and this, in turn, can promote a reduction of H+ in the particles area vicinity. The process can be demonstrated in figure.14. In Ni-Co-WC, cobalt has been added as a binder phase, Smaller WC grains dissolved in Co-solution and re-precipitate on large WC grains, the final product consists of the denser homogenous nanostructure of WC grains with cobalt as a binder phase matrix[38,39]. 3.4.2 Formation of the oxide film as the anti-corrosion layer in acidic media. Passivation behavior occurs due to the formation of oxide film on the metal surface, which protects the underlying metal by passivation behavior. In Ni-WC coating layer
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
the passivation due to formation of oxide film of tungsten, The oxidation reactions of tungsten is shown in equations,
WC + H2O ↔ WO3 + CO2 + 10H + +6e- (6) In Ni-Co-WC passivation behavior due to oxidation of tungsten and cobalt on the metal surface .Cobalt is always covered by a native passive film which consists mainly of CoO or CoO.H2O. Co + H2O ↔Co (H2O)ads (7) Co(H2O) ↔ Co(OH) ++ H++ 2e- (8) Although that cobalt corrodes actively in acid media and forms oxides at pH levels above 7 only in oxygenated environments. In acidic media, CoOH+ + H+ ↔ Co2+ +H2O (9) and continuous dissolution of cobalt or its passive film takes place, which explains the high rates of corrosion recorded[33][34].

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Composite coating of metallic-ceramics tungsten carbide (WC) in nickel matrix successfully achieved by direct current (DC) electrodeposition using watt's bath solution on stainless steel substrate. The presence of WC particles in the nickel coatingThe addition transforms surface morphology from regular pyramidal to more "open-like" cauliflower structure. The addition of cobalt enhances surface morphology, as cobalt have a larger radius than tungsten form more "open-like" structure.
M AN
US CR
IP T
AC CE
PT ED
As a load of WC increase in the solution the grain size of Ni decrease and enhance the hardness of the composite, as a result of adding cobalt to the system hardness increase dramatically than Ni coating. The open circuit potential of Ni-8g/l WC was much nobler than the substrate, Ni coating, and Ni-Co-WC. Polarization measurements indicate that Ni-8g/l WC had best corrosion protection to the under lying metal lead to the decrease in corrosion current density and increase in corrosion potential. The corrosion resistance of the coating doesn’t contain Co was better than that containing Co in acidic media due to cobalt oxide film dissolution in acidic media and micro galvanic corrosion occurred between WC particles and Co binder metal which lead to corrosion of anodic binder. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy results exhibit that the charge transfer resistance values of Ni-8g/l WC alloy coatings were higher compared to Ni coating and lower double-layer capacitance.
M AN
US CR

Research Highlights:
• Ni-WC and Ni-Co-WC were deposited by simple and economic
electrodeposition method.
• Addition of metallic ceramics tungsten carbide enhances surface morphology. • Hardness of coating increase by addition WC and increase dramatically by
adding Co.
• Ni-WC creates corrosion passivation behavior. • The coating layer is stable after corrosion tests.

metadata.abstractText: Composite coating of metallic-ceramics tungsten carbide (WC) in nickel matrix has been achieved by direct current (DC) electrodeposition using watt's bath solution on stainless steel substrate. The deposition parameters such as current density, bath temperature, and stirring rate were maintained at constant levels for all the coating configurations. The surface morphologies, microstructure, and chemical composition of the composite coating were studied using scanning electron microscope (SEM), Xray diffraction (XRD), and energy dispersive analyzer x-ray system (EDX), respectively. The surface morphology and microstructure analysis showed that the composite coatings form cauliflower-like grain colonies, grain size was calculated from Scherrer equation it was less than 60 nm for all composite coating. Micro hardness of composite coating was increased by increasing WC load in solution and decreasing grain size. The electrochemical corrosion behavior of composite coating was evaluated by potentiodynamic polarization measurements and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) in aerated 0.5 mol/l H2SO4 at room temperature, showing passivation behavior of all composite coating, good protection of Ni-8g/l WC on stainless steel substrate.
